fields.name: Calm Breathing for Anxiety
fields.description: A gentle breathing exercise designed to calm racing thoughts and reduce anxiety symptoms.
instructions: Find a comfortable seated position with your back straight but relaxed.
Close your eyes or soften your gaze downward.
Take a deep breath in through your nose for 4 counts.
Hold your breath gently for 4 counts.
Exhale slowly through your mouth for 6 counts.
Repeat this cycle for the duration of the meditation.

fields.name: Loving-Kindness for Depression
fields.description: Cultivate self-compassion and connection to counter depressive thoughts and isolation.
instructions: Begin by finding a comfortable position and closing your eyes.
Place your hand on your heart and feel the gentle pressure.
Start by offering loving-kindness to yourself: 'May I be happy. May I be healthy. May I be safe. May I live with ease.'
Next, think of someone you love easily and extend the same wishes to them.
Then include a neutral person, someone you neither like nor dislike.
Finally, extend these wishes to all beings everywhere.
If difficult emotions arise, return to offering kindness to yourself.

fields.name: Progressive Body Scan for Stress
fields.description: Systematically release tension throughout your body to relieve stress and promote relaxation.
instructions: Lie down in a comfortable position with arms at your sides.
Close your eyes and take three deep breaths.
Begin with your toes, noticing any sensations without judgment.
Consciously relax your toes, then move to your feet.
Continue this process up through your legs, torso, arms, and head.
Spend about 30 seconds on each body part.
If you notice tension, breathe into that area and let it soften.
End by feeling your whole body relaxed and at ease.

fields.name: Mindful Movement for Anger
fields.description: Channel intense emotions through gentle, mindful movement to find balance and calm.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Begin by shaking your hands gently, then more vigorously.
Let the shaking move up your arms and through your whole body.
After 2 minutes, slow down and come to stillness.
Place your hands on your belly and take 5 deep breaths.
Begin slow, flowing arm movements, like moving through water.
Focus on the sensations of movement rather than thoughts.
End in stillness, noticing how your body feels now.

fields.name: Zen Breathing for Focus
fields.description: Traditional Zen meditation to sharpen concentration and mental clarity.
instructions: Sit in a comfortable upright position, either cross-legged or in a chair.
Keep your eyes half-open with a soft downward gaze.
Place your dominant hand on top of the other, thumbs lightly touching.
Begin counting your breaths: inhale (1), exhale (2), up to 10, then start again.
When you lose count, simply return to 1 without judgment.
After 10 minutes, stop counting and just follow the breath.
If thoughts arise, acknowledge them and return to the breath.
Maintain this focused awareness for the remainder of the session.
